author: phillipsj
body:
I followed the direction located [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/install/installing-powershell-core-on-linux?view=powershell-6#installation-via-package-repository-preferred---fedora-27-fedora-28).

And I receive the following error:

sudo dnf install powershell
Repository packages-microsoft-com-prod is listed more than once in the configuration
Last metadata expiration check: 0:05:34 ago on Tue 12 Feb 2019 08:19:37 PM EST.
No match for argument: powershell
Error: Unable to find a match


# Steps to reproduce

1. Start with a fresh install of Fedora 29
2. Install Microsoft .NET Core following directions [here](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/linux-package-manager/fedora28/sdk-current).
3. Follow directions to install PowerShell Core from [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/install/installing-powershell-core-on-linux?view=powershell-6#installation-via-package-repository-preferred---fedora-27-fedora-28)

# Expected behavior

That there wouldn't be a naming conflict that prevents searching the repository to find the PowerShell package.

# Actual Issue

Both the .NET Core package repository and the PowerShell package repository for Fedora both use the same package name which cause the conflict.

## .NET Core
[packages-microsoft-com-prod]
name=packages-microsoft-com-prod
baseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/fedora/27/prod/
enabled=1
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc

## PowerShell
[packages-microsoft-com-prod]
name=packages-microsoft-com-prod
baseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/rhel/7/prod/
enabled=1
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc

# Workaround

I just opened the *microsoft.prod* repo file that was created and edited it to change the repository name.

[packages-microsoft-com-pwsh]
name=packages-microsoft-com-pwsh
baseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/rhel/7/prod/
enabled=1
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc

# Actual Resolution

Either change the name of one of the package files or create a single repo that all Microsoft packages can be obtained.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT @TravisEz13 Please look the Issue - this may need to be fixed before the next release.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @phillipsj I just created a new Fedora 29 VM and following the instructions it installed powershell 6.1.3 just fine.

comments.author: phillipsj
comments.body:
Did you follow all my repro  steps or did you just do the PowerShell
install.  You have to install the other Microsoft repo and try to install dotnet too.  That is the
conflict.

On Tue, Feb 19, 2019, 6:34 PM Steve Lee <notifications@github.com wrote:

> @phillipsj <https://github.com/phillipsj> I just created a new Fedora 29
> VM and following the instructions it installed powershell 6.1.3 just fine.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8879#issuecomment-465356117>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABfthSVO8-bFjEz3bJG9O8Avrg7SK6cnks5vPIoHgaJpZM4a4aDp>
> .
>

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @phillipsj sorry, didn't install dotnet.  I see what the problem is.  At the time we started publishing pwsh, packages.microsoft.com only had rhel and didn't have a folder for fedora.  They have that now which is what dotnetsdk uses.  The problem is if you follow both instructions, then the Microsoft repo is registered twice differently which `dnf` complains about.  The fix is that we should also publish to the fedora location and update our install instructions.  cc @TravisEz13

comments.author: phillipsj
comments.body:
No worries, I really enjoy using Powershell and want it to be seamless.
Thanks for looking into it.

comments.author: phillipsj
comments.body: This issue isn't resolved, this applies to all fedora installations including Fedora 30. I feel that you all didn't try to reproduce this issue.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I see the request is to publish individual packages for each fedora distribution.  Can you open a feature request?

comments.author: phillipsj
comments.body:
That isn't the request.  The request is to not name your repo the same as
the .net core repo in your yum file.
